metadata.label: Content description
metadata.value: This commercial letter starts with extensive blessings and greetings for the addressee Abū Isḥāq Ibrāhīm b. Yāqūt, who is addressed in the rest of the letter as "my brother" and with a more polite form of address (l. 7 ḥaḍratuka). The addressee is located in Cairo where the sender visits him regularly (l. 12; l. 9). Two men have come from Maghrib, the sender writes, who have told him that the Maghreb is so full that people started to emigrate (l. 10-11). On the verso side the sender announces that there is good wheat for sale in his town eight waybas for one dinar and bread costs three arṭāl for one dirham. This was apparently a good price as he adds that this constituted a great blessing (l. 5). The sender discusses the price of textiles in Cairo. He also writes that a request to buy a turban for a certain Abū Aʿlā could not be met for less than one and a half dinar (ll. 7-9). Abū Aʿlā's request to buy him chickpeas, however, the sender was able to fulfill for a price of fifty dirham (l. 9). The sender finally writes that something was included in his letter.
